I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has supported the government of Balochistan (the 
government)  in  public  resource  management  reforms  through  the  Balochistan  Resource 
Management Program (BRMP I). BRMP I was approved in November 2004,1 and closed after 
the release of the second tranche on 31 May 2007. In total, BRMP I provided $130 million to 
assist  the  government  of  Balochistan  to  (i)  enhance  provincial  finances  through  fiscal 
restructuring  and  better  financial  management,  and  (ii)  improve  processes  and  establish 
appropriate institutions for public service delivery and private sector development. In early 2007, 
the government requested further ADB support to sustain the first phase of reforms. An ADB 
mission visited Quetta and Islamabad during 3–12 September 2007 to reach general agreement 
on  the  scope  of  the  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  required  to  prepare  the  second 
Balochistan Resource Management Program (BRMP II).2 The design and monitoring framework 
is in Appendix 1. Appendix 2 presents the initial social and poverty analysis. Details on costs are 
in Appendix 3, with implementation arrangements outlined below. Appendix 4 presents the 
outline terms of reference for the preparation of BRMP II, which will be processed in the second 
quarter of 2008.3
II.  ISSUES 
2.  ADB’s country strategy and program for Pakistan4 has good governance at its core. This 
emphasis is reflected in ADB’s lending portfolio and several important governance programs 
have been approved over the last 7 years.5Public resource management—the implementation 
of public policies through fiscal, administrative, and political arrangements—is a key element of 
governance  that  has  received  significant  attention  in  recent  years,  particularly  in  light  of 
Pakistan’s decentralization reforms, which began in August 2001.   
3.  BRMP I was successful not only in initiating systemic thinking on strategic reforms in the 
government and with other stakeholders but also in implementing certain fundamental policy 
changes. Balochistan had an open-ended subsidy system for electricity for operating agricultural 
tube wells, which accounted for about 8% of provincial current expenditure and had increased 
by 150% between fiscal year (FY) 2001 and FY2006. Through BRMP I, the subsidy was capped 
at PRs2 billion in nominal terms (about 5% of provincial expenditure in FY2007). This decision 
was taken despite the fact that most of the larger landowners, the principal beneficiaries of the 
subsidy, had considerable political influence. The water resource component of BRMP I has 
provided a firmer institutional basis for better water resource management through the adoption

made possible by using ADB’s ordinary capital resources loan to retire the more expensive cash 
development loans of the province from the Federal Government, thus saving over PRs1 billion 
per annum in debt servicing costs. Initial revenue management reforms have begun to take 
effect: revenue receipts from tax and nontax sources increased by an impressive 58.2% in 
FY2006  over  the  previous  year,  although  the  increase  in  tax  revenue  was  only  8%.  The 
recovery of irrigation water charges has picked up under an action plan supported by BRMP I. 
The “throw forward” of Balochistan’s public sector development program has been reduced 
under BRMP reforms.6 Another fundamental policy achievement was the establishment of a 
rule-based transparent system of local government funding. Moving forward, there are three 
sets of constraints. 
4. The fiscal and public financial management reform agenda is incomplete. While
the government has taken a number of important steps7 to improve fiscal discipline, further short 
and medium-term reforms are required over the next one to five years to (i) strengthen the 
planning and budgeting systems, and adopt a medium-term expenditure framework  to enhance 
the credibility, predictability, comprehensiveness, and transparency of the budgeting process;8
(ii)  gradually  phase  out  the  remaining  subsidies  that  are  deemed  to  be  inefficient; 9
(iii)  strengthen  property  and  agriculture  tax  administration,  at  both  provincial  and  local 
government levels; (iv) improve pension administration and contingent liability management;10
and (v) strengthen accounting, internal control, and audit systems.11
5. Serious issues remain in institutional and human resource management. BRMP I 
introduced reforms that enhanced the autonomy of the Public Service Commission, updated the 
government rules of business, and introduced third party audit and pubic grievance redress 
mechanisms. However, the overall number and structure of provincial line departments need to 
be reviewed. Business processes also need to be improved, particularly in agencies dealing 
with development and revenue collection, and those with extensive citizen interface. The human

have to appear. In this case, the throw forward was reduced from almost 10 years in 2004 to 4 years in 2007.

8  BRMP II will continue to strengthen the devolution agenda. Under the Balochistan Local Governance Ordinance, 
2001 the provincial government is no longer a direct implementer exercising complete administrative and financial 
control. Under the ordinance, it is now required to define the policy and regulatory frameworks and ensure they are 
observed at the local level. This requires a more complex and sophisticated monitoring and analysis role, and 
building capacity at the local level.  
9  Following the capping of the tube well subsidy under BRMP I, a scheme to phase out the subsidy scheme was 
developed under ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for Strengthening Program 
Implementation for Balochistan Resource Management Program. Manila.

pending in the provincial assembly.

3
resource management regime is outdated and does not encourage or offer incentives for good 
performance.  Proper  training,  career  management,  and  human  resources  databases  are 
needed. The difficulty of attracting high-quality civil servants to accept transfers and postings in 
Balochistan  has  to  be  addressed  through  incentive  mechanisms  and  business  process 
improvements that improve efficiency. 
6. Asset management remains weak. Balochistan’s geography and weather patterns put 
significant  pressure  on  its  water  resources.  Ineffective  water  resource  management  and 
misdirected subsidies have diverted fiscal resources from other high-priority areas. Building on 
progress made under BRMP I (para. 3 above), the next generation of reforms may include the 
creation of and support to a water regulatory authority and strengthening of other institutions, 
including area water management boards. Strategic planning and monitoring and evaluation 
capacities in the Irrigation Department are quite weak and need to be further strengthened.  
7.  Balochistan has a rich cultural heritage and the government is the custodian of one of 
the most ancient civilizations in human history.12 Proper protection13 and preservation of this 
heritage is essential if it is not to be lost forever. Strategic marketing of Balochistan’s cultural 
treasures has the potential to bring in additional revenue from raising awareness14 and, if it is 
linked to the local services industry (e.g., crafts and tourism), it could create jobs. In addition, 
recognition and promotion of Balochistan’s unique heritage would help to bridge the cultural and 
ethnic divides in the province, which would have further dividends in the form of improved law 
and order and private sector growth.
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  This project preparatory TA aims to help the government develop the next generation of 
public administration reforms to be pursued under BRMP II.15 Such continuation and deepening 
of  policy  reforms  in  fiscal  and  financial  management,  public  administration,  and  asset 
management will free resources for pro-poor development and better public service delivery. 
This in turn is likely to improve the economic and social outcomes in the province. The expected 
outcome is greater fiscal space for the province of Balochistan through enhanced flows and 
improved management of resources, as further detailed in the design and monitoring framework 
(Appendix 1). 
9.  These outcomes will be achieved through diagnostic and analytical work under the TA, 
with wide stakeholder consultations (involving the government, civil society groups, and the 
private sector, among others). Several policy papers will be prepared to help formulate the 
reform agenda under BRMP II. The consultative nature of the process will raise awareness and 
build capacity to coordinate policy development.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will fund (i) national and international experts to undertake studies and policy 
analysis,  and  to  develop  the  policy  reform  agenda  for  BRMP  II;  and  
(ii) workshops to promote participation by civil society and other stakeholders and incorporate 
their feedback in the policy reform process. The TA will build on recommendations of previous 
policy-based lending operations and public resource management programs.16
11.  The studies will also build on the reforms already achieved or initiated under BRMP I 
and  subsequent analytical work such as the first Balochistan Economic Report and Public
Financial Management and Accountability Assessment,17 supported by ADB and the World 
Bank. The workshops will encourage stakeholders to scrutinize the impact and initial results of 
BRMP I. Outcomes of such workshops/consultations will be published on the BRMP website. 
Close  collaboration  with  other  development  partners  is  also  envisioned  so  that  the  policy 
dialogue under the BRMP II is well coordinated. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $450,000 equivalent in local currency costs. ADB will 
provide $400,000 equivalent on a grant basis from ADB’s TA funding program. The government 
of Balochistan will contribute the remaining local currency cost of $50,000 equivalent in kind by 
providing office accommodation, counterpart staff, and facilities for seminars and meetings. 
Appendix 3 presents the cost estimates and financing plan. The government has been informed 
that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. The Government 
of Pakistan has also been informed of the scope of the TA.
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The  Executing  Agency  (EA)  for  the  TA  will  be  the  Finance  Department  of  the 
government of Balochistan. Implementing agencies will include the Departments of Planning 
and Development, Excise and Taxation, Board of Revenue, Culture, Irrigation and Services and 
General Administration. The BRMP program management unit will coordinate the TA activities 
on behalf of the EA. The TA is expected to begin in January 2008 and will be implemented over 
7  months.  All  consultants  will  prepare  inception  reports  on  their  work  assignments  within            
4 weeks of the commencement of services. They will also reconfirm the work program and 
establish time-bound outputs. The consultants will also produce final reports, preceded by 
interim pieces as appropriate, together with clear recommendation of policy reform measures, 
other proposed activities, and realistic milestones that could be achieved under BRMP II. The 
final reports, which will include complete documentation of all outputs, will be submitted within 1 
month of the end of the assignment. 
14.  Procurement  will  be  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as 
amended from time to time). No major procurement of goods is envisaged under the TA. Supply 
contracts valued below $10,000 may be directly purchased from the supplier.

I.  POVERTY ISSUES 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
Public  resource  management  deals  with  processes  and  mechanisms  for  mobilizing  revenues  and  allocating  them  to 
development purposes. Effective public resource management will increase revenues, and improve the allocation efficiency of 
public expenditures. It will lead to higher socioeconomic returns, improve the access of the poor to public services, and 
promote  private  sector  development  and  employment  generation.  Governance  reforms,  including  public  resource 
management, are a central element of ADB’s country poverty analysis and country strategy and program. BRMP II will 
strengthen the performance orientation of the budget, free up resources for expenditures on reducing poverty, and improve the 
responsiveness of the civil service to the public's needs, particularly for the delivery of pro-poor services. 
B.     Targeting Classification          
1.  Select the targeting classification of the project: 
 General Intervention    Individual or Household (TI-H);  Geographic (TI-G);  Non-Income MDGs (TI-M1, M2, etc.) 
2.   Explain the basis for the targeting classification:  
Public resource management programs are governance reforms which indirectly reduce poverty.
C.  Poverty Analysis 
1.  If the project is classified as TI-H, or if it is policy-based, what type of poverty impact analysis is needed?
No full poverty analysis is required, but the project will consider available poverty assessments in Balochistan. 
2.  What resources are allocated in the PPTA/due diligence? 
No specific funds will be allocated since the project will build on existing poverty analysis in Balochistan. 
2.  If GI, is there any opportunity for pro-poor design (e.g., social inclusion subcomponents, cross subsidy, pro-poor 
governance, and pro-poor growth)? 
BRMP II will continue funding performance incentive grants for local governments (as under BRMP I).  An evaluation of the 
success of the grants is currently being undertaken by the Department of Finance of Balochistan.

The project intends to improve governance structures in Balochistan.

    The project intends to improve governance structures in Balochistan and is not directly targeting certain beneficiaries.

The TA is a continuation of policy dialogue which started under BRMP I, which funded several workshops. The workshops

conduct a Balochistan Development Forum before fact-finding for the program.

follow-up;
(viii)  ensure that recommendations of evaluation reports of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) on (a) the performance of the TA, (b) policy-based lending, and  
(c) public resource management programs are taken into consideration;   
(ix)   ensure sound donor coordination and draft a donor coordination matrix;  
(x)   participate  in  missions  and  other  assignments  leading  to  preparation  of  the 
BRMP II; and
(xi)   perform any other activity, consistent with the above terms of reference, assigned 
to him or her by ADB. 
2.  Financial Management Specialist (national, 6 person-months) 
3.  The  specialist wll prepare papers and studies that will investigate (i) strengthening 
provincial  revenues  and  revenue  management;  (ii)  rationalizing  provincial  development 
expenditures;  and  (iii)  improving  effectiveness,  predictability,  and  accountability  in  financial 
management by modernizing system management (accounting, treasury functions, contingent 
                                                
1  ADB. 2007. Balochistan Economic Report: From Periphery to Core. Quetta (forthcoming); 2004. Balochistan. 
Public Financial Management and Accountability Assessment. Quetta.

Appendix 4  13
liabilities), improving budgeting process (including the introduction of a medium-term budget 
framework  and  medium-term  expenditure  framework),  and  fiscal  responsibility  and  public 
disclosure mechanisms. 
4.  The specialist will have at least 10 years’ experience in financial management and an 
understanding of and experience in Balochistan. He or she will work under the direction and 
supervision of the governance and finance advisor. 
5.  The studies to be prepared by the financial management specialist will include areas 
agreed with the Executing Agency. They will be submitted as a series of short reports covering 
the following areas. 
a.  Fiscal and Financial Management 
(i)  Report on existing accounting, reporting and monitoring systems, procedures 
and processes being practiced by the provincial government for federal transfers 
and  for  the  province’s  own  sources  of  revenue.  The  report  will  provide 
recommendations, an action plan, and formats for improving the reporting and 
monitoring  of  federal  transfers  according  to  National  Finance  Commission 
awards and other federal transfers, as well as performance against targets of the 
province’s own sources of revenue.  
(ii)  Report  on  existing  systems,  procedures  and  processes  of  the  provincial 
government  for  management  and  accounting  of  off-system  funds,  personal 
ledger accounts, and vertical programs. The report will provide recommendations 
and  an  action  plan  for  improvements,  as  well  as  suggested  formats  and 
procedures for managing, accounting, and monitoring such funds. 
(iii)  Report  on  existing  systems,  procedures  and  processes  of  treasuries  in 
Balochistan,  recommending  improvements  in  management  and  inspection  of 
treasuries.
(iv)  Report  on  existing  systems,  procedures  and  processes  of  the  provincial 
government for accounting, reporting and monitoring the General Provident Fund 
and Pension Fund. The report will provide recommendations and an action plan 
for improving the management of contingent liabilities. 
b.  Budget 
(i)  Report  on  provincial  expenditure  budgeting,  with  proposals  for  improved 
processes for (a) budgeting, including approval and sanction of establishment 
strength,  capital  (development)  expenditure,  and  current  expenditure;  
(b) agreements on cash flow and expenditure with provincial departments and 
agencies;  (c)  implementation  of  expenditure  allocations  for  non-salary 
expenditure;  and  (d)  rationalizing  commitments  and  phasing  of  development 
expenditure.
(ii)  Report  on  managing  provincial  departments’  expenditures  with  proposals  for 
introduction of (a) improved budget execution and reporting by the provincial 
departments and agencies, and (b) improved monitoring and reconciliation by the 
finance department. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
c.  Accountability 
(i)  Report on the present functioning of the Public Accounts Committee as well as of 
the accounts committees of local governments. Make proposals to improve the

14 Appendix 4 
functioning of these committees in the context of post-audit actions for improved 
accountability.  
(ii)  Prepare a draft of fiscal responsibility legislation. 
d.  Enhancing Revenue Base 
(i)  Report on the province’s own source revenues, reviewing the steps taken to 
implement commitments to improve these revenues under BRMP I and other 
initiatives of the provincial government.  
(ii)  Make proposals and present an action plan to enhance the revenue base and to 
continue rationalizing economic services, the Mines and Minerals Department, 
and  other  areas,  including  royalty  and  dividend  expenditure  from  provincial 
government investments. 
e.  Transparency, Public Disclosure, and Access to Information 
(i)  Review the transparency, public disclosure, and access to information in the 
workings of provincial and local governments.  
(ii)  Recommend improvements in rules and procedures for improved transparency, 
disclosure and access to information.  
(iii)  Support preparation of annual reports by the provincial government on oil and 
gas revenues. 
6.  Based  on  the  studies  and  analysis  carried  out  above,  the  specialist  will  (i)  make 
recommendations for fiscal and financial management reforms to be undertaken under BRMP II 
and present a specific time-bound action plan for implementation, (ii) participate in missions and 
other  assignments  leading  to  preparation  of  BRMP  II,  and  (iii)  perform  any  other  activity, 
consistent with the above terms of reference, assigned to him or her by the governance and 
finance advisor. 
3.  Economist (national, 4 person-months) 
7.  Based  on  inputs  from  other  consultants,  the  economist  will  (i)  prepare  briefs  and 
presentations on each program area, and (ii) be responsible for preparing all the documentation 
required to process the program in keeping with the ADB requirements. 
8.  The  economist  will  have  at  least  10  years’  experience  as  an  economist,  in-depth 
knowledge of and experience in the procedures, systems and program processing requirements 
of ADB, and a thorough understanding of resource management, public finance, and poverty 
issues in Pakistan. He or she will work under the direction and supervision of the governance 
and finance advisor. 
9.  The tasks of the economist will include the following: 
(i)  based on inputs from TA consultants, prepare briefs and presentations on each 
program area specifying the advantages of the proposed policy actions (and the 
implications if the proposed actions are not taken) for all components of the 
program;
(ii)  work closely with the governance and finance advisor on the policy matrix and 
work plan, and, based on inputs from other TA consultants, prepare the policy

Appendix 4  15
matrix and work plan and participate in discussions with the government for its 
finalization; 
(iii)  coordinate with TA consultants to prepare all the documentation needed for the 
processing of the program, including the design and monitoring framework, policy 
coordination  matrix,  social  and  policy  analysis,  gender  analysis,  and  other 
requirements;
(iv)  participate  in  missions  and  other  assignments  leading  to  preparation  of  the 
BRMP II; and
(v)  perform any other activity, consistent with the above terms of reference, assigned 
to him or her by ADB. 
B.   Institutional and Human Resource Management Reforms 
1.  Institutional Specialist (national, 5 person-months)  
10.  The  specialist  will  undertake  a  study  on  (i)  developing  a  diagnostic  framework  to 
rationalize  and  strengthen  the  institutional  arrangements  of  the  provincial  government 
departments, and (ii) improving the business processes in select government departments to 
enhance their efficiency and effectiveness. The consultant will provide an overall policy direction 
for the reform agenda under BRMP II, with a specific, time-bound, measurable implementation 
action plan for the policy interventions. The consultant will share the study findings with the 
stakeholders through structured workshops and obtain feedback to inform the analysis and 
recommendations. 
11.  The consultant will have qualifications related to public administration or management, 
with at least 10 years’ experience in public administration reforms and change management. 
Knowledge of and experience in Balochistan will be an asset. 
12.  The tasks and outputs of the specialist will include the following:
(i)  review, in the light of the constitutional mandate and obligations of the provincial 
government, the allocation of business within its departments and agencies and 
identify any misalignment; 
(ii)  prepare specific recommendations to amend the rules of business of the provincial 
government based on (i) above and the mandates of the local governments defined 
under  the  Balochistan  Local  Governance  Ordinance,  2001  (and  their  rules  of 
business);
(iii)  conduct a review of business processes in selected departments (Planning and 
Development and Mines and Minerals), map out in detail the workflows and the 
business  processes  to  identify  issues  and  make  specific  recommendations    for 
improvement  (including  clearly  identified  amendments  to  rules  and  instructions 
where required); 
(iv)  for the Planning and Development Department, the review will cover in detail the 
social sector, the infrastructure sector and the natural resources sector; 
(v)  for  the  Mines  and  Mineral  Department  the  review  will  cover  the  licensing, 
concessions, and royalty and other fee collection;  
(vi)  propose  reforms,  including  detailed  recommendations  on  rules  of  business  and 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
business processes and government procedures for implementation under BRMP II; 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
(vii)  will conduct wide stakeholder consultations, including with civil society; 
(viii)  participate in missions and other assignments leading to preparation of BRMP II; and

16 Appendix 4 
(ix)  perform any other activity, consistent with the above terms of reference, assigned to 
him or her by ADB. 
2.  Human Resource Management (HRM) Specialist (national, 4 person-months) 
13.  The specialist will (i) prepare a study on a framework for identifying and removing 
weaknesses in the human resource management practices in the public sector, and (ii) provide 
an overall policy direction for the reform agenda under BRMP II, with a specific time-bound, 
measurable implementation action plan. The specialist will share the study findings with the 
stakeholders through structured workshops and obtain feedback to inform the analysis and 
recommendations. 
14.  The consultant will have qualifications related to human resource management or public 
administration with at least 10 years’ experience in human resources management. Knowledge 
of and experience in Balochistan will be an asset. 
15.  The tasks and outputs of the specialist will include the following:
(i)  review the regulatory framework (including the Civil Servants Act, rules and other 
regulations)  governing  recruitment,  career  management,  tenure,  capacity 
building, performance evaluation and the incentive structure; 
(ii)  review  the  functioning  of  the  Public  Service  Commission,  the  Services  and  
General Administration Department, and the public sector training institutions; 
(iii)  identify major issues and make recommendations on the broad direction for 
policy  reforms  under  BRMP  II,  including  a  framework  for  further  detailed 
evaluation where necessary; 
(iv)  provide a specific and measurable, time-bound implementation action plan for 
immediate implementation and/or piloting under BRMP II; 
(v)  consult  widely  with  stakeholders,  including  members  of  civil  society  and 
recipients of public services;  
(vi)  participate  in  missions  and  other  assignments  leading  to  preparation  of  the 
BRMP II; and
(vii)  perform any other activity, consistent with the above terms of reference, assigned 
by ADB. 
C.   Provincial Natural and Cultural Asset Management 
1.  Specialist in Water Resources Policies (national, 2 person-months) 
16.  The  specialist  will  be  responsible  for  preparing  all  the  documentation  required  for 
processing the program in keeping with ADB requirements. 
17.  He or she will have at least 12 years’ experience and must have in-depth knowledge of 
and experience in the procedures, systems, and program processing requirements of ADB, and 
a thorough understanding of water resources policies in Pakistan. He or she will work closely 
with the team leader of the cofinanced TA under BRMP I on water resources management.2
                                                
2  ADB. 2004. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on Proposed Loans and 
Technical Assistance Grants to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for the Balochistan Resource Management 
Program. Manila.

Appendix 4  17
18.  The tasks of the specialist will include the following:  
(i)  review existing work on the water sector in Balochistan, in order to (a) prepare a 
concise action plan for water resource management; (b) propose time-bound policy 
reform actions for inclusion under BRMP II, and (c) review the water resource policy 
framework  in  view  of  its  social  provisions  and  possible  impacts  on  involuntary 
resettlement and indigenous people;
(ii)  participate in missions and other assignments leading to preparation of the BRMP II; 
and
(iii)  perform any other activity, consistent with the above terms of reference, assigned to 
him or her by ADB. 
2.  Heritage Management Specialist (international, 2 person-months) 
19.  The heritage management specialist will have at least 15 years’ experience in cultural 
asset management.
20.  The  tasks  of  the  specialist  will  include  the  following:  prepare  an  overview  of 
archeological assets in Balochistan in collaboration with the relevant departments to include      
(i) ownership issues; (ii) rules and regulations (e.g., their applicability and any omissions); (iii) an 
overview of the cultural assets, particularly from Mehrgarh, that can be exhibited in a world-
class exhibition in one or more countries; (iv) proposals on how revenues can be generated 
through such cultural marketing; and (v) proposals on how such revenues can best be used to 
house and preserve cultural assets in Balochistan. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.
